Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Supporting and Advancing Geoscience Education at Two-year Colleges through Workshops and Web Resources

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project engages community college and other two-year college (2YC) geoscience faculty members in a targeted professional development program that shares successful strategies for teaching students with a range of abilities, experiences, and goals, and for preparing 2YC students for the geoscience workforce. Included in this project are: (1) two topical workshops, one on effective strategies for teaching all students and the other on workforce development through geoscience education at 2YCs; (2) an associated website of 2YC geoscience resources; (3) four types of dissemination workshops (national, regional, local, and virtual); and (4) a leadership development program for 2YC geoscience faculty members. The project develops effective models of professional development for full-time and adjunct 2YC geoscience faculty members, establishes networks of 2YC and 4YC faculty members and administrators focused on 2YC education, and builds leadership within the 2YC geoscience community. Furthermore, the project synthesizes resources to address challenges in 2YC geoscience education. The topical and dissemination workshops enable 2YC faculty members to discuss issues, challenges, and opportunities, to share effective strategies and examples, to meet new colleagues, to prepare action plans to improve curriculum and instruction, and to develop sustainable professional communities.

Strong undergraduate geoscience education is dependent on effective programs at 2YCs. 2YCs play an increasingly important role in producing earth-science literate citizens, developing a competent and creative geoscience workforce, teaching science to pre-service K-12 teachers, and providing a foundation for broadening participation in the geosciences. 2YC faculty members face substantial challenges - limited resources for travel, isolation, and few opportunities for geoscience professional development specific for their setting. By engaging 2YC geoscience faculty members in professional development, this project disseminates advances in STEM education to improve teaching, supports students in geoscience technical training, and helps prepare geoscience majors and pre-service teachers for college transfer. Online resources enable dissemination beyond workshop participants and are an important resource for both 2YC faculties and the broader geoscience community. Within the great diversity of the 2YC students, this project helps broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities in the geosciences by increasing their involvement in 2YC programs and by preparing them for enrollment in four-year institutions or for the geo-technical workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supporting and Advancing Geoscience Education in Two-year Colleges (SAGE 2YC) is a multi-year national professional development program for full-time and adjunct geoscience faculty in two-year colleges (2YCs) that supports the continued growth of a vibrant 2YC geoscience faculty community and builds leadership within the 2YC geoscience community. The workshop topics are focused on two project themes: (1) strategies for preparing 2YC students for the geoscience workforce (geotechnician training, geoscience career information and career advising, and supporting transfer to four-year colleges and universities) and (2) strategies for supporting student success in 2YCs including strategies for teaching students with a range of experiences and goals (e.g., strategies to promote self-regulated learning, undergraduate research in two-year colleges, supporting English-language learners, and supporting the whole student).

Intellectual merit: We developed a program model to collect, synthesize, and disseminate resources on the two main project themes and to offer a range of professional development opportunities for 2YC geoscience faculty. Our program model includes national workshops that serve to collect and synthesize resources; three types of dissemination workshops: workshops held in association with professional society meetings, regional workshops, and local workshops; a webinar series; a website used to support the workshops and to extend the research of the program; and a leadership development program that engaged 2YC geoscience faculty to design, publicize, and lead local workshop with the advice and support of SAGE 2YC leaders. Online resources on topics related to supporting workforce, transfer, and careers and to supporting student success, developed in association with the workshops, expand program reach (http://serc.carleton.edu/sage2yc/index.html). Both the national and dissemination workshops enable 2YC faculty to discuss issues, challenges, and opportunities on topics of interest to them; to share effective strategies and examples; to meet new colleagues; to prepare action plans to improve curriculum and instruction; and to develop professional networks and communities.

Broader impacts: We offered two national workshops, four workshops at professional meetings, two regional workshops, 16 local workshops, a webinar series, and developed a website with resources focused on the two project themes. Participation in SAGE2YC workshops has been broad and diverse and included 335 geoscience professionals who attended a SAGE 2YC workshop: 78% are 2YC faculty, 16% are faculty from four-year colleges and universities (4YCUs), and 6% are from professional organizations or employers. Participants came from 190 institutions, including 144 2YCs and 29 4YCUs. The workshops are effective in reaching women (57% of workshop seats), underrepresented minorities (>9% of workshop seats), and adjunct faculty (>21% of workshop seats). The regional and local workshops had higher rates of participation by adjunct faculty. The workshops enabled 2YC faculty and others interested in 2YCs to discuss issues and share effective strategies, develop collegial relationships, plan and implement instructional and programmatic improvements, and develop sustainable professional communities. Participants reported an expanding vision and sense of responsibility for promoting geoscience careers and changes in practice in their courses, their advising, and their programs. The local workshops were led by teams of 2YC faculty; these local workshops served to disseminate topical resources, provide opportunities for participants to discuss strategies and network, and focus on issues and/or implementation strategies most applicable to the local area. Online resources enable dissemination beyond workshop participants and are an important resource for both 2YC faculty members and the broader geoscience community.

Factors that contributed to program success include 1) leaders with 2YC experience; 2) a focus on topics of interest and importance to 2YCs; 3) well-designed workshops that engage participants and include individual action planning; 4) multiple types of dissemination workshops to reach diverse faculty; and 5) mentored leadership development for 2YC geoscience faculty.

Dissemination of results has occurred through the project website, peer-reviewed publications, and presentations at national geoscience conferences.
